contentfulPage.title: How much you’re paid
contentfulPage.metaDescription: Find out how pay is determined, including details of pay ranges and contribution-based pay.

childMarkdownRemark.html: This information is for employees on Buckinghamshire County Council’s CBP Terms and Conditions. Your pay depends on the pay range you’re in and the amount of contribution-based pay you receive. This is called Contribution Based Pay or CBP, and if you’re on CBP you’ll get a pay statement in July every year telling you how your performance relates to your salary

Every employee is assigned to a particular pay range. The scale goes from R1 to R12 and then from SM1 to SM5.

Within each pay range, the amount varies depending on the overall contribution you make to your job – a fair and cost effective way of setting pay which reflects an individual’s input to our work.

You will get a pay statement in July every year telling you how your performance relates to your salary. This will be recorded in your Delivering Successful Performance (DSP) record.

Most people who do well in their jobs will be at the Competent point of pay, depending on their start date. But your salary can be decided anywhere between the Entry and Advanced point, and there is no single step move from Competent to Advanced. All pay progress depends on the CBP scheme.

No time-based increases

There are no time-based increases, so it doesn’t matter how long you’ve worked for us – your pay only goes up if you work well in your job. And your salary will never go down through the CBP scheme.

No cost of living rises

Your salary also won’t change as the cost of living rises (or falls) – there are no inflation-based increases.

Your CBP statement

You will receive a CBP statement in July which you can see online via SAP. The actual CBP pay review date is 1 July. Your performance rating applies to the pay range you were paid on 31 March, which is the end of the performance calculated year.

How your pay is reviewed

If you want to understand how your pay is linked to your performance, you will need to know your:

  • Delivering Successful Performance (DSP) rating
  • Position in your pay range at 31 March.

Once you have this information you can work out how your pay changes every July, using the CBP Matrix.

childMarkdownRemark.html: If you’ve recently joined the council on CBP terms, you will usually be placed at the new starter level (entry point) on the pay range, unless there is a good reason to be placed above this.
If you get promoted, your pay rate will either be the entry point for your new pay range or 2.5% more than the pay you were getting – whichever is more.

Sometimes it's hard to fill certain posts, for example if they are very specific and need certain skills. We may need to offer more money to attract the right candidate. There will need to be a business case that sets this out as a need before we can go ahead and advertise the post.

collapsibleLinks.title: Contribution Based Pay on a temporary contract

childMarkdownRemark.html: If you’re working for us on a temporary contract from an agency, you may still be entitled to Contribution Based Pay. Your manager will set this up and review your work objectives with you so you can receive the appropriate hourly rate.
